 The rule of thumb for developed countries is 65% of GDP on internal transactions. The US has been running at 75%+, with the bulk of the excess furnished by public (primary) and consumer debt. While the US has a huge internal market, that's an advantage only if we're producing our own goods. We're not and our trade deficit is averaging around $40 billion/month, another massive drain of the country's wealth. The soft dollar has not helped our exports to any great degree as we're in the process of migrating from an industrial to service sector, with the bulk of the trade imbalance (90%) in durable goods, not services. Government influences such as allowing the dollar to decline, tariffs to protect grossly overpaid and benefited jobs and massive military/government spending are tired political exercises in expanding the GDP for better numbers to sooth the public while in reality they reduce consumer purchasing power without a corresponding increase in real income as provided by true economic growth. 
 
 As we don't have more money chasing fewer goods but a devalued currency chasing abundant goods with no industrial demand for expansion credit, leaving interest rates at rock bottom, IMO we're not experiencing true inflation, we're just feeding on our national wealth. We are experiencing alarming trade deficits, amassing annual public debt getting near the actual federal operating budget with little debt service requirements due to current interest rates, have realized substantial reduced tax revenues over the past three years, all with no sign of anyone pulling up on the reins.
 
 I personally see no possibility of increasing federal tax revenues due to the decline of our industrial sector and resultant loss of investment and wage income. Foreign investors have been fleeing from our equity markets, dominated by pension funds capable moving the numbers of public companies trading at or above book values up and down at will. Our national debt service is a ticking time bomb, as is our trade imbalance, also financed at low interest rates. Over the past two years I've watched the shift of resources for social spending being pushed down from a federal level, displaced by expanded military and human resource spending, to local levels where tax increases have often been horrendous. Most US State constitutions bar them from incurring public debt for purposes other than education or transportation improvements. 
 
 Not a pretty picture, and certainly not a situation that can be sustained on an indefinite basis with our voracious appetites for imported oil, durable consumer goods and unilateral military agression, all on borrowed money. I consider the employment issue a red herring.
